om.helper
Class Match

java.lang.Object
  om.helper.Match

public class Match
extends java.lang.Object

The Match class is used to test if a string satisfies a set word pattern matching rules.

Examples:

 Match m = new Match("one two three");
 m.match("three one two"); // returns true
 m.match("three two one go"); // returns true
 m.allowExtraWords = false;
 m.match("three two one go"): // returns false
 m.match("three two honey"); // returns true
 m.allowExtraChars = false;
 m.match("three two honey"); // returns false
 m.allowAnyWordArder = false;
 m.match("three one two"); // returns false

 m.setPattern("one$two three$four"); // '$' means 'or'
 m.match("one two"); // returns false
 m.match("two three"); // returns true

 m.setPattern("&oto&s#s"); // '&' means any string, '#' means any char
 m.match("photosynthesis"); // returns true
 m.match("fotosynthesis"); // returns true
 m.match("fotosinthesis"); // returns true
 m.match("fotosinfisys"); // returns true
 m.match("photasynthesis"); // returns false
(Note: This is Chris Denham's code. I just copied it in here. --sam)

Field Detail

allowExtraChars

public boolean allowExtraChars
This field controls whether or not extra characters in a word are to be permitted. For example, if the pattern is "abc" and this field is set to a value of true, this will successfully match with strings such as "abcde" or "abacab". If this field is set to a value of false , only the string "abc" will match the pattern "abc".

This field has a default value of true.

allowAnyWordOrder

public boolean allowAnyWordOrder
This field controls whether or not words in the match string must appear in the same order as the words in the pattern. For example, if the pattern is "Mary had a little lamb" and this field is set to a value of true, this will successfully match with strings such as "Mary lamb had a little".

This field has a default value of true.

allowExtraWords

public boolean allowExtraWords
This field controls whether or not words that are not in the pattern are permitted match string. For example, if the pattern is "banana" and this field is set to a value of true, this will successfully match with strings such as "Eat a banana today".

This field has a default value of true.

Method Detail

setPattern

public void setPattern(java.lang.String pattern)
Sets the pattern that we want to test strings against. The pattern is a set of one or more words (each word separated by a space). To get a match, all of the words in the pattern must match with a word in the string you are matching against. Extra control of the matching process can be achieved using the '&', '#' and '$' characters. If you want to use these characters literally, precede them with the backslash character.
'&' means match any string.
'#' means match any character.
'$' match with the preceding OR the next word.
See the examples above for details of usage.

Parameters:
pattern -

match

public static boolean match(java.lang.String response,
                            java.lang.String pattern)
This function is only provided for compatibility with OpenWin oMatch class. The preferred method for using this class would be to create an instance of the Match class and control its mode through the object's fields.

Parameters:
response -
pattern -
Returns:
whether the response matches the pattern.

match

public boolean match(java.lang.String response)
Tests whether the specified string satisfies the pattern matching rules.

Parameters:
response -
Returns:
if the response matches the pattern, this method returns a value of true, otherwise it returns false.
